'''Sandusky Mall''' is an indoor [[shopping center]] located in [[Perkins Township, Erie County, Ohio
column2: Perkins Township]], south of [[Sandusky, Ohio]].  It is located on the east side of [[US Route 250
column3: US 250]] (Milan Road), north of [[Interstate 80 in Ohio
column6: SR 2]]. It is the only major shopping center within 45 miles. The mall comprises more than 70 stores including two [[anchor stores
column7: anchor stores,]] [[JCPenney]], and Hobby Lobby. The mall has two sub anchors, Books-A-Million, and TJ Maxx. There are two vacant anchors currently last occupied by [[Macy's]], and [[Elder-Beerman]]. JCPenney had previously operated a store in downtown Sandusky.<ref>{{cite news
column9: title=Ohio town feels effect of new mall
column13: accessdate=August 10, 2010}}</ref> It is managed by [[Cafaro Company]] of [[Youngstown, Ohio]].

column1: Mall construction began in 1976 and Sandusky Mall opened in 1977. Its original anchors included [[JCPenney]], [[Elder-Beerman]], [[The May Department Stores Company]] (simply the May Co.), and [[Montgomery Ward]] (later [[Sears]] in 1986). The outdoor section, [[Child World]] closed in 1992 and later converted to [[OfficeMax]] in 1994, then closed in 2005. It was converted to K&K Home Furnishings in 2006, then closed in 2014. It later converted to a Planet Fitness in 2015.

The May Co. rebranded their store at the Sandusky Mall as [[Kaufmann's]] in the mid-1990s. In 2006, the store was converted to [[Macy's]], when May Department Stores Company and Federated Department Stores merged into Macy's, Inc. [[Borders Group
column3: TJ Maxx]] was added in 2009. Borders closed in 2011. A few months later, it was replaced by [[Books-A-Million

column1: On April 7, 2016, Sears announced that its store would be closing in June 2016.<ref>http://www.sanduskyregister.com/story/201701040044</ref>

On January 4, 2017, Macy's announced that its store would also be closing as part of a plan to close 100 stores nationwide over the next several years. The store closed in March 2017.<ref>http://www.sanduskyregister.com/story/201701040044</ref>
On April 18, 2018, it was announced that Elder-Beerman would be closing all of their stores after the parent company, Bon-Ton became bankrupt. The store closed late August 2018.
In December 2018, Cafaro Company announced that they had a redevelopment plan set in place for the mall with chances on the horizon coming within the next year.
[[File:Sandusky Mall Viewed From Back of Nearby Mcdonald's Lot.jpg
column4: Picture of the mall taken by YouTuber, \"Tom's Terrific Retales\"]]

column1: On June 30, 2019, It was announced that Hobby Lobby, a crafts/ home decor store would be coming to the Sandusky Mall. They will replace a little over half of the former Sears store. It opened March 23rd, 2020.
The mall is being transformed into a mix-used property to feature residential, entertainment, and even office space. Changes are currently underway.

The mall features Tenants such as JCPenney, Hobby Lobby, BAM!, TJMaxx, American Eagle, Bath and Body Works, Victorias Secret, Kay Jewelers, Journeys, Spencers, Express Factory, Zales Jewelers, Hot Topic, Finish Line, Shoe Department Encore, Christopher & Banks, and more.

The malls Food Court offers Asian Express, Auntie Anne's, Lotus Garden, Mrs. Fields, and Cheers Sports Bar & Grill. The Food Court is located in the west corridor, or can be accessed through the main entrance outside. The mall also has a coffee shop located in Books-A-Million. Restaurants surrounding the mall include McDonalds, Cracker Barrel, Red Lobster, and Texas Road House. As you can see the mall complex has various dining options.

link,safe,Unoquha,"'''Sir William Keith of Delny''' (d. c. 1605) was a Scottish courtier and keeper of the Royal Wardrobe.
William Keith was a son of Andrew Keith, laird of [[Ravenscraig Castle, Aberdeenshire
column2: Ravenscraig]], Aberdeenshire, and only distantly related to the Earls Marischal. In 1579 he was made a valet in the household of [[James VI of Scotland]].<ref>Miles Kerr-Peterson, [https://www.euppublishing.com/doi/abs/10.3366/inr.2016.0124 'Sir William Keith of Delny', ''Innes Review'' 67:2 (2016), pp. 138-158], at pp. 140, 142.</ref>

column1: King James granted William Keith lands in [[Delny]] in Ross in 1586 for good service as Master of the Wardrobe.
In 1587 Delny was sent to England with [[Robert Melville, 1st Lord Melville
column2: Sir Robert Melville]] of Murdocairny and the [[Patrick Gray, 6th Lord Gray
column3: Master of Gray]] to intercede for the life of [[Mary, Queen of Scots]]. Their speeches and manner of mediation was said to have been counter-productive.<ref>''Calendar State Papers Scotland'', vol. 9 (Edinburgh, 1915), p. 564.</ref>

column1: In July 1589 it was expected that Delny and the English courtier [[Roger Aston]] would lose their places at court because they had been supporters of the Master of Gray, who was now out of favour. Their opponents, the followers of the [[George Gordon, 1st Marquess of Huntly
column2: Earl of Huntly]] and [[John Seton, Lord Barns
column4: Barnes]] called Aston, Keith, and the [[Walter Stewart, 1st Lord Blantyre
column5: Lord Privy Seal]], \"Queen Elizabeth's pensioners\".<ref>''Calendar State Papers Scotland'', vol. 9 (Edinburgh, 1915). p. 448-9, 452, 453: ''Calendar State Papers Scotland'', vol. 10 (1936), pp. 127-9.</ref>

column1: Delny was in the retinue which accompanied King [[James VI of Scotland
column2: James VI]] to [[Norway]] and [[Denmark]] to collect his future Queen, [[Anne of Denmark]].<ref>''Calendar State Papers Scotland'', vol. 10 (Edinburgh, 1936), pp. 170-1.</ref> During the trip, the king sacked him as keeper of the wardrobe, allegedly for appearing in richer clothing than himself, and appointed [[George Home, 1st Earl of Dunbar
column3: Sir George Home]] in his stead.<ref>''Calendar State Papers Scotland'', vol. 10 (Edinburgh, 1936), pp. 276, 478.</ref> In the days before Delny lost his place, a correspondent of [[Francis Walsingham]] wrote on 5 April 1590 that the Chancellor [[John Maitland, 1st Lord Maitland of Thirlestane
column4: John Maitland of Thirlestane]] aimed to discredit the Earl Marischal and Delny, but Delny was \"wonderfully well beloved\" and had \"ever worn his sword on the right and true side\".<ref>''HMC Salisbury Hatfield'', vol. 3 (London, 1889), p. 403.</ref>

column2: Robert Bowes]] noted in July 1591 that Delny \"lay in bed\" once or twice at [[Morham
column3: Morham Tower]] with the owner, the rebellious [[Francis Stewart, 1st Earl of Bothwell]].<ref>''Calendar State Papers Scotland'', vol. 10 (Edinburgh, 1936), p. 551.</ref>

column1: Delny regained royal favour in June 1592 apparently by the intervention of Anne of Denmark in the controversy between the Earl Marischal and the [[Lord Chancellor of Scotland
column2: Lord Chancellor]], [[John Maitland, 1st Lord Maitland of Thirlestane
column3: John Maitland of Thirlestane]].<ref>''Calendar State Papers Scotland'', vol. 10 (Edinburgh, 1936), p. 687.</ref>

column1: Delny became an associate of [[Ludovick Stuart, 2nd Duke of Lennox]]. On 6 May 1593 the Duke and 15 friends subscribed to a frivolous legal document swearing to abstain from wearing gold and silver trimmings on their clothes for a year, and defaulters were to pay for a banquet for all of them at John Killoch's house in Edinburgh. This \"[[Passementerie
column2: passement]] bond\" was in part inspired by cheap counterfeit gold and silver thread used in \"passements great or small, plain or ''à jour'', bissets, lilykins, cordons, and fringes\" which quickly discoloured. The signatories included; [[Alexander Home, 1st Lord Home
column3: Lord Home]], the [[John Erskine, Earl of Mar (1558–1634)
column4: Earl of Mar]], [[Alexander Lindsay, 1st Lord Spynie
column6: Master of Glamis]], [[Thomas Erskine, 1st Earl of Kellie
column7: Sir Thomas Erskine]], [[Walter Stewart of Blantyre]], and [[George Home, Earl of Dunbar
column8: Sir George Home]].<ref>''Historical Manuscripts Commission, Appendix 4th Report: Mrs. Erskine Murray'' (London, 1874), p. 527.</ref>

column1: In 1594 Delny carried invitations to the [[Masque at the baptism of Prince Henry
column2: baptism and tournament]] at [[Stirling Castle]] for [[Henry Frederick, Prince of Wales
column3: Prince Henry]] to the Dutch Republic. Sir [[James Melville of Halhill]] said he was not suited the role because he could not speak French, Latin, or Flemish.<ref>Thomas Thomson, ''Memoirs of his own life by Sir James Melville of Halhill'' (Edinburgh, 1827), p. 411.</ref>

column1: In April 1597 James VI asked Delny to correspond with Venice, to bolster support for his accession to the throne of England.<ref>''Calendar State Papers Scotland'', vol. 11 (Edinburgh, 1952), p. 507.</ref>

column3: London University]] and became a fellow in 1882.<ref>{{cite web

column1: Before he attended University he had started to train as an accountant and was employed as a clerk. After University he became a chartered accountant and later became Borough Accountant of Abingdon.<ref name=OBP/> In 1887 he was called to the Bar at [[Gray's Inn]]. In 1891, he lived at the home of his widowed mother at Piccadilly House in Ock Street before marrying Lydia Jacobs of Burford in October 1895.<ref name=OBP/> He was the master of Abbey Lodge in 1893.
The couple purchased Whitefield in 1896 (14 Albert Park) at the time.<ref>{{cite web
column4: publisher=The Abingdonian}}</ref> The property today is the used as a health and medical centre for Abingdon School. He continued his career as a Chartered Accountant and Barrister at Law and was a founder member of the Institute of Chartered Accountants. He was the Borough Council accountant for twenty-two years.<ref name=gov/> He became a governor of Abingdon School from 1902-1942 and was Chairman of the Governors from 1937-1939 and a life Governor of Christ's Hospital in 1909.<ref name=obit>{{cite web

column1: He retired in 1908 and devoted his later years to public service. He was elected to Berkshire County Council in 1895 and in 1909 served three years as Mayor of Abingdon.<ref name=OBP/> He was Chairman of the County Council Finance Committee and a county magistrate.<ref name=gov/> He was an Alderman of both County and Borough councils and on the Thames Conservancy Board and was made an Honorary Freeman in 1932.<ref name=OBP/> In 1922, he financed a major archaeological project in regard to the demolished 1538 Abbey church and in 1928 helped securing Waste Court for Abingdon School, where he remained as a Governor for the rest of his life and was Chairman from 1937-1939. In 1935, he financed a major ceiling restoration in the St Helens' Lady Chapel.<ref name=gov/><ref name=obit/>

He dedicated much of his time into researching the history of Abingdon and built up a large collection of documents and employing staff to transcribe and translate documents. He wrote several historical books including the '''St Nicholas Abingdon and Other Papers''' published in 1929, which covers the history of St Nicholas' Church, Abingdon School, and Fitzharris Manor.
He continued to finance Abingdon projects including the refurbishment of the Guildhall and [[John Roysse
column2: Roysse Room]] (the original schoolroom of Abingdon School). He also helped restore Albert Park and founded the Abingdon Bowling Club and was co-founder of the Frilford Heath Golf Club.<ref name=gov/> <ref name=OBP/> He was also a President of the [[List of Old Abingdonians

column1: Preston died in 1942 while still residing at Whitefield, his wife Lydia died one year later.<ref name=obit/>

He was the founder of Pariyatti Shiksha (Buddhist education) in the country, and in 2006 was named the fifth Sangha Nayaka (Chief Prelate).<ref name=\"ekantipur\">{{cite news

Sapta Ratna was born to father Purnananda and mother Surjamaya Vajracharya in Kwa Baha, [[Kathmandu]]. In 1940, he went to [[Kushinagar]], India, and was ordained as a novice monk. He was given the dharma name Buddhaghosa. He then went to [[Burma]], where he studied Buddhism and meditation, and in 1943 received higher ordination as a full monk in [[Mandalay]]. He was the first from a [[Vajracharya]] family to become a Theravada monk.<ref name=\"ekantipur\" />
Returning to Nepal, Buddhaghosa (alternative names: Bhante Buddhaghosa, Buddhaghosa Mahathero) lived at the monastery of Sumangal Vihar in [[Lalitpur District, Nepal
column2: Lalitpur]] and dedicated himself to spreading the Buddha's message.<ref>

'''Radiation exposure''' is a measure of the ionization of [[air]] due to [[ionizing radiation]] from [[photon]]s; that is, [[gamma ray]]s and [[X-ray]]s.<ref> ''Knoll'', p. 56</ref> It is defined as the [[electric charge]] freed by such radiation in a specified volume of air divided by the [[mass]] of that air.

column2: SI]] unit of exposure is the [[Coulomb (unit)
column3: coulomb]] per [[kilogram]] (C/kg), which has largely replaced the [[roentgen (unit)
column4: roentgen]] (R).<ref>''Holmes-Siedle and Adams'', p. 4</ref> One roentgen equals {{val
column7: up=kg}}; an exposure of one coulomb per kilogram is equivalent to 3876 roentgens.

column1: As a measure of [[radiation damage]] '''exposure''' has been superseded by the concept of [[absorbed dose]] which takes into account the absorption characteristic of the target material.

Dose is the measure of energy per unit mass deposited by ionizing radiation. For a given radiation field, the absorbed dose will depend on the type of matter which absorbs the radiation. For instance, for an exposure of 1 [[roentgen (unit)
column2: roentgen]] by gamma rays with an energy of 1 [[MeV]], the dose in air will be 0.877 [[rad (unit)
column3: rad]], the dose in [[water]] will be 0.975 rad, the dose in [[silicon]] will be 0.877 rad, and the dose in averaged [[tissue (biology)
column4: human tissue]] will be 1 rad. A table giving the exposure to dose conversion for these four materials for a variety of gamma ray energies can be found in the reference.<ref>Carron, p. 141</ref>

column1: The gamma ray field can be characterized by the exposure rate (in units of, for instance, [[roentgen (unit)
column2: roentgen]] per hour). For a point source, the exposure rate will be linearly proportional to the source's [[radioactivity]] and inversely proportional to the square of the distance,<ref>Knoll, p. 57</ref>

column1: '''Frank Clifford Last''' (13 December 1918 – 1991)<ref>https://www.freebmd.org.uk/cgi/information.pl?r=140467824:2202&d=bmd_1586250123</ref><ref>https://www.imdb.com/name/nm8500049/bio?ref_=nm_dyk_trv_sm#trivia</ref> was an [[English people
column2: English]] [[sculptor]], the son of [[Nella Last]], author of a [[World War II]] diary on which the TV film ''[[Housewife, 49]]'' was based.

column1: Clifford Last was the younger son of Nella and William Last, [[Shop fitting
column2: shopfitter]] in [[Barrow-in-Furness]], [[England]]. He had an older brother, Arthur. After war service in which he lost his closest companion and was injured himself, he trained in art and emigrated to [[Australia]] in 1947, becoming a noted sculptor. Some of his works are displayed in the National Gallery of Australia and the [[Ballarat Fine Art Gallery]] in the [[States and territories of Australia

column1: Last was a foundation member of Centre Five, a group formed in 1960 to promote contemporary abstract sculpture in Australia. The group, originally called Centre Four, was founded in 1953 by [[Hungary
column2: Hungarian-born]] Julius Kane, featuring Last, [[Norma Redpath]] and [[Germany
column3: German-born]] [[Inge King]]. Centre Five was a splinter group of the Victorian Sculptors' Society comprising members Clifford Last, [[Inge King]], Vincas Jomantas, [[Teisutis Zikaras]], Julius Kane and [[Lenton Parr]]. They shared common characteristics in their style and felt that exhibiting together would be to their advantage. Their aim was to foster the understanding of modern sculpture among Australian architects and the public.<ref>{{Cite news

column1: The project was problematic in that they had resigned from the Victorian Sculptors' Society and in effect set themselves up as competition. The result was a severe split in the very small sculpture world of the time, the repercussions of which are still felt today. Due to the nature of the split, the Society – formed to promote the work of members – missed out on official consideration.<ref>{{Cite web
}}</ref> Last later was a member of the Commonwealth Art Advisory Board.<ref>{{cite book

Materials with which Last worked included bronze, slate, wood and aluminium. Using wood as his favoured medium, Last furthered his studies at the [[Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology]]. After he spent fourteen months back in England in 1950–1951, Last’s work took on a more geometrical form. He explored the use of shapes that he believed demonstrated the emotions existing in family groups and then explored subjects such as [[Dualism (philosophy of mind)
column2: dualism]] and [[Trinity]] through the manipulation of religious references and symbols.

column1: Last preferred the work to speak for itself and, unless asked, opted not to go into detail.<ref>{{Cite web
He carved wood such as [[Eucalyptus marginata
column2: Jarrah]], using, for example, the [[cruciform]] shape in relativistic relationships which left interpretation open. One such form could refer to animals, plants, icons, people or groups.

column1: A fine example of his large-scale bronzes entitled \"Family\" was commissioned by the [[Government of Australia]], in 1971, as an official gift to the international organization, [[Asian Development Bank]], which displays it in its headquarters in [[Manila]].
Last's mother Nella died in 1968 and his father less than one year later in 1969. Last remained in Australia and died there in 1991.

column1: The Military Academy of Cavalry was established in [[Giza]] at [[Mourad Bey Palace]], which was turned into a cavalry barracks. '''Charles Mason Hovey''' (October 26, 1810, [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]] - 1887) was an American nurseryman, seed merchant, journalist and author of horticultural books best known for his two-volume large [[quarto]], ''The Fruits of America''<ref>{{cite web
column5: accessdate=2012-08-01}}</ref>  published between 1848 and 1856 and containing some 100 [[chromolithographs]] by [[William Sharp (lithographer)
column6: William Sharp]], the British-born lithographer and artist, with an extremely rare third volume which was partly published.<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=Donald Heald Original Antique Books Prints and Maps - Books

column1: Hovey was an honorary member of the Royal Societies of London and of Edinburgh.

Charles was the sixth of seven children born to Sarah Stone Hovey and Phineas Brown Hovey, who ran a grocery store at the comer of Main and Brookline Streets, and dealt in the sale and rental of property in Cambridge. In 1832 Hovey and his brother Phineas started ''Hovey & Co.'', a seed store and nursery in Cambridge, the nursery eventually growing to 40 acres in extent.<ref>{{cite web
column6: accessdate=2012-07-30}}</ref> Hovey set out to publish a magazine that would appeal to gardeners and showcase the various American fruits of interest. He became the editor of the ''Magazine of Horticulture'' published between 1835 and 1868, founded as ''The American Gardener's Magazine'' with a name change in 1837. It enjoyed a longer life than any other American horticultural journal and was modelled on [[John Claudius Loudon]]'s ''Gardener's Magazine''.<ref>{{cite web

column1: Hovey collected cultivars of pear, apple, plum and grape, also cultivating florist and ornamental plants, with a particular fondness for ''[[Camellia]]'' and ''[[Chrysanthemum]]''. He exhibited regularly with the [[Massachusetts Horticultural Society]] and was its president for four years. He was responsible for producing the ''Hovey Strawberry'' in 1836, regarded as the foundation of the [[New England]] strawberry industry, and grown on a large scale until about 1890. Hovey wrote a seminal article \"''Some Remarks upon the Production of new varieties of Strawberries from Seeds''\" that was published July 1837 in his ''Magazine of Horticulture'', and in which he gave detailed instructions for producing hybrids.<ref>{{cite web

column1: Hovey was a great champion of open spaces and wrote in the ''Magazine of Horticulture'': \"We need not enlarge upon the importance of public parks, certainly, if they were more numerous they would prevent the useless expenditure of money for lunatic hospitals. '''Charles Mason Hovey''' (October 26, 1810, [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]] - 1887) was an American nurseryman, seed merchant, journalist and author of horticultural books best known for his two-volume large [[quarto]], ''The Fruits of America''<ref>{{cite web
column5: accessdate=2012-08-01}}</ref>  published between 1848 and 1856 and containing some 100 [[chromolithographs]] by [[William Sharp (lithographer)
column6: William Sharp]], the British-born lithographer and artist, with an extremely rare third volume which was partly published.<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=Donald Heald Original Antique Books Prints and Maps - Books

column1: Hovey was an honorary member of the Royal Societies of London and of Edinburgh.

Charles was the sixth of seven children born to Sarah Stone Hovey and Phineas Brown Hovey, who ran a grocery store at the comer of Main and Brookline Streets, and dealt in the sale and rental of property in Cambridge. In 1832 Hovey and his brother Phineas started ''Hovey & Co.'', a seed store and nursery in Cambridge, the nursery eventually growing to 40 acres in extent.<ref>{{cite web
column6: accessdate=2012-07-30}}</ref> Hovey set out to publish a magazine that would appeal to gardeners and showcase the various American fruits of interest. He became the editor of the ''Magazine of Horticulture'' published between 1835 and 1868, founded as ''The American Gardener's Magazine'' with a name change in 1837. It enjoyed a longer life than any other American horticultural journal and was modelled on [[John Claudius Loudon]]'s ''Gardener's Magazine''.<ref>{{cite web

column1: Hovey collected cultivars of pear, apple, plum and grape, also cultivating florist and ornamental plants, with a particular fondness for ''[[Camellia]]'' and ''[[Chrysanthemum]]''. He exhibited regularly with the [[Massachusetts Horticultural Society]] and was its president for four years. He was responsible for producing the ''Hovey Strawberry'' in 1836, regarded as the foundation of the [[New England]] strawberry industry, and grown on a large scale until about 1890. Hovey wrote a seminal article \"''Some Remarks upon the Production of new varieties of Strawberries from Seeds''\" that was published July 1837 in his ''Magazine of Horticulture'', and in which he gave detailed instructions for producing hybrids.<ref>{{cite web

What most people know as monkey bread today in the United States is actually the Hungarian dessert ''[[arany galuska]]'' (\"golden dumpling\"). Dating back to the 1880s in Hungarian literature, Hungarian immigrants brought this dish with them when they immigrated to America and began introducing it into the country's food landscape when Hungarian and Hungarian Jewish bakeries began selling it in the mid-twentieth century.{{cn

In 1972, a cookbook published by Betty Crocker included a recipe for ''arany galuska'', which they referred to as \"Hungarian Coffee Cake\". As it became more popular in America, ''arany galuska'' came to be confused with monkey bread in which the balls of dough are not dipped in cinnamon and sugar but only in butter. \"Monkey bread\" soon became the more common name for this Hungarian Jewish dessert.<ref name=\"Marks2010\">{{cite book
Recipes for the bread first appeared in American [[women's magazine]]s and community cookbooks in the 1950s, but the dish is still virtually unknown outside the United States.{{cn

}}</ref>  It is traditionally served hot so that the baked segments can be easily torn away with the fingers and eaten by hand.<ref>{{cite web

The '''New Mexico Spaceport Authority''' is a non-governmental panel, appointed by the [[Governor of New Mexico]], whose members represent the public sector in the development and construction of [[Spaceport America]], a facility that is expected to enter operation as the first privately operated active [[spaceport]] in the United States.<ref name=\"Phase I\">{{cite web
column3: title=Spaceport America near Las Cruces heads into Phase II

column1: Spaceport America was built with [[U.S. state
column3: bond]] funding provided by county debt. Two-thirds of the $212 million used to build the spaceport was paid by the [[State of New Mexico]] with the rest provided by bonds backed by Doña Ana and Sierra county,<ref name=ept20101023>

column4: title=New era draws closer: Spaceport dedicates runway on New Mexico ranch
column9: quote=''two-thirds of the $212 million required to build the spaceport came from the state of New Mexico...  The rest came from construction bonds backed by a tax approved by voters in Doña Ana and Sierra counties.''

column1: which will be partially repaid by locally generated gross receipts tax revenues.

The state of [[New Mexico]] has privatized the operations of Spaceport America; the spaceport will be operated by [[Virgin Galactic]], a component of the [[Virgin Group]] of global companies operated by Sir [[Richard Branson]].  While the Spaceport Authority will exercise public-sector oversight, Virgin Galactic will be the \"anchor tenant\" of the spaceport.<ref name=\"Phase I\"/>
In February 2011, the governor of New Mexico appointed Christine Anderson as executive director of the Spaceport Authority.<ref name=\"NMSA-Anderson\">{{cite web
column3: title=Governor Susana Martinez Announces Christine Anderson as Spaceport Executive Director
column8: archivedate=2011-07-19 }}</ref>  In April 2011, the Authority announced that its budget for fiscal year 2012 had been reduced by 57 percent.<ref name=\"NMSA-Budget\">{{cite web
column10: title=NM spaceport authority discusses 57 percent budget cut and spending plan
column16: fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>  In March 2012, the Authority announced that it had completed what it called ''Phase I'' of the Virgin/Spaceport America construction project.  This Phase I included a 10,000-foot runway, a terminal hangar, and a domed Space Operations Center.  Phase II, the visitor center and actual liftoff pad, remained unbuilt as of March 2012.<ref name=\"Phase I\"/>

column1: The current status of Virgin Galactic, the sole prospective tenant of the New Mexico Spaceport and its Authority, has led members of the New Mexico legislature to sharply question Executive Director Anderson. After an [[VSS Enterprise crash
column2: incident on October 31, 2014]], Virgin Galactic indefinitely postponed its planned operational startup date in New Mexico. '''The Loch Ard Gorge''' is part of [[Port Campbell National Park]], [[Victoria (Australia)
column2: Victoria]], Australia, about three minutes' drive west of [[The Twelve Apostles (Victoria)

column1: The gorge is named after the [[clipper ship]] ''[[Loch Ard (ship)
column3: ran aground]] on nearby Muttonbird Island on 1 June 1878 approaching the end of a three-month journey from England to [[Melbourne]].  Of the fifty-four passengers and crew, only two survived: Tom Pearce, at 19 years of age, a ship's apprentice, and Eva Carmichael, an Irishwoman emigrating with her family, at 19 years of age.<ref>{{cite news
column6: newspaper=[[Australasian Sketcher with Pen and Pencil]]
column13: via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> According to memorials at the site, Pearce was washed ashore, and rescued Carmichael from the water after hearing her cries for help.  Pearce then proceeded to climb out of the gorge to raise the alarm to local pastoralists who immediately set into plan a rescue attempt. After three months in Australia Carmichael returned to Europe. Four of her family members drowned that night. Pearce was hailed as a hero, and continued his life living until age 49. He is buried in Southampton, England.

column3: Cemetery for the Loch Ard passengers]]

column3: title=Island Archway near Loch Ard Gorge loses its archway
column9: archivedate=14 June 2009 }}</ref> They have since been officially named Tom and Eva after the two teenage survivors of the Loch Ard shipwreck.<ref>{{Cite web
